comment: I wish we could filter the comments by level of positivity. I am truly fighting back tears at the number of negative, evil, malicious, and ugly comments on here---by both men and women. These comments are the EXACT reason we need more songs and images like this in HEAVY ROTATION. We are all human and as such we all thrive on unconditional acceptance and love. Not talking about sycophantic worship---I'm talking about that deep down spiritual love and recognition that we all need. That simple but POWERFUL need to be validated as important and appreciated to those we know and love. I pray that all those on here who have made such bigoted and unkind remarks would find someone in their lives to love them and accept them the way John Legend sings about. Your comments indicate that you don't have that type of love in your lives---what a sad way to live.

author: aminenewin

comment:
Why are guys being so selfish???? They like, oooooo John Legend didn't make a vid about my gender, so total dislike. Sure, guys AND girls can be critical about the way they look and have low self esteem. But it's been proven that guys tend to view themselves as more attractive than girls do.

Â I watched this Discovery Channel documentary about the science of sex/dating/love, (I WAS CURIOUS DON'T JUDGE PLEASE) and they did this study where random men and women were shown two identical pictures of themselves, but one had digitally enhanced features. When asked which picture better reflected their personality, more men chose the enhanced picture than women.

Of course, this is just a generalization. Everyone's different, and your self esteem depends on a lot of things. But for one thing, only 1% of breast cancer victims are men. The social/physical differences between male and female breasts cause much more self esteem damage for women with breast cancer than with men.

All in all, I loved the song, the video, and the message it came across. Lets just try not to forget that, guy or girl, we can all feel pain, and we're all human.Â

comment: Based on what I can see of the comments, John Legend should have put this video out ages ago. The blatant misogyny and transphobia is appalling. Ignorant bigots are getting choked up with the big words they're using but don't understand in the threads below. Men talking about how they feel like they're the victims in the grand scheme of things because women get treated so well in our society is enough to bring bile to my mouth. Demeaning these women (because they are ALL women) is part of the privilege that we as a male-dominated society exercise on women in order to subjugate them and steal their agency. Also, Laverne Cox was a women before and after her surgery (btw her surgery is none of our business). Sexual confirmation surgery is only meant to synchronize her body with her identity. She and the rest of the women in this video, and the world, deserve our respect!Â

comment: This song exemplifies the very essence of what beauty means to us. The saying goes, "beauty is in the eye of the beholder". This also applies to art, in this case it's the exhibition of women of different shapes, sizes, physical features that epitomize the true meaning of beauty. No one person is ugly, everyone has beauty no matter how shallow, cruel, or fake you are as a person. Many good people out there degrading themselves because they feel the need to please society, why not just be yourself, and stop hiding behind something you're not. Anyways I'm rambling, all in all, being only raised by my mother, I've seldom looked at a woman and said a negative comment about her physicality. We must all be willing to cultivate a better society, and in doing so incorporate, and create RESPECT. Great song John Legend, you're the very definition of how music should be written, composed, and performed

comment: I just can't get over how empowering this song is. I (and I think many) can personally relate to being weakened by someone's negative opinion often from people I care deeply about, sometimes over things I had no control over such as my appearance or ethnicity. It's hard to accept that one person's opinion of us does not define us and that everyone (not just women, men too) have worth and value. For some of us it's difficult to accept, but something I hope everyone will one day: we all have value don't waste it and don't let anyone tell you otherwise. (:

comment:
It's interesting to know how many women/girls need validation from men/society to let them know how beautiful they are. I guess I'm lucky in a way because when I look in a mirror,  and I look like crap, I accept it. Also when I look in the mirror and I look beautiful I accept it just the same. 

Now if someone wants to give me their unsolicited advice/feedback on my looks ( my man, sister, girlfriends, coworker) I'd either thank them, or tell them to f off, either way I accept me  and that's more than enough.

Don't get me wrong, I'm grateful to my man when he tells me I'm beautiful. I simply don't need to ask him "do I look fat in this dress?" Because the mirror will let me know if I look  bad, and if i do, I change my clothes. I also wish my girlfriends wouldn't ask me those types of questions, because I feel like this: if YOU like it and it's appropriate for where you're going. Just where it.

Sorry for the rambling. Hope you understand what I mean.

author: TheAs57

comment:
Wow I guess secularism has demolished consensus by negating objectivity and elevating preference (no objectivity or parameters of beauty, sexuality, morality etc. and ultimately human identity - a loss of meaning). I think therefore I am (I'm referring to this video calling people beautiful who are clearly suffering from conditions). Fascinating how no one thinks they're a giraffe or something else random like a car. Fascinating how many intellectuals think like this at the dinner table and not in the lab. Why did humanism evict life truth?

And why deny the plight of the deformed or stricken because of a skewed sense of equating beauty with goodness? Their resilience goes unnoticed and uncommended. Resilience to being so beautiful? Is that why the woman with breast cancer teared? Does disease bring beauty? Or does a philosophy of a culture without a point of reference construct a diseased sensuous point of reference that tears a person who feels they cannot be accepted without conforming to the idea that "beauty is goodness or merit." Can one be inherently ugly but wondrously good?

This video has great intent to honor some distressed people but it has a disturbing point of reference (or lack thereof with regard to beauty). Writing this comment on youtube is probably tossing pearls before swine (not in the assumed value of my comment but in the level of its thought). Whatever.
author: thebullybuffalo

comment: What can we do to stop this? We can stop putting so much emphasis on physical beauty. Stop telling little girls and boys, "Oh you're so pretty/handsome!" Instead, tell them, "Oh you're so smart and creative!" When you watch a movie with young people, don't talk to them about how hot the characters are, talk to them about the depth and meaning of the character's actions. When you buy toys for children, don't invest in the toys that focus on manly men or beautiful women, buy them building blocks and things that will test their creativity and engineering skills. When you buy clothes, don't search for clothes that make you look good. You are not the item to be shown off, you are not an extension of the clothes. Buy clothes that look good on you. The clothes are to be shown off, and they are an extension of your personality. (I know that's confusing, think of it as a change of mindset). When you find yourself thinking only about a person's physical beauty, and evaluating them on it, stop and remind yourself that they are human, and they are much more valuable than their body. Practice these changes of mindset and habit, and you will make a difference.

comment:
Where's the song telling me that I'm still valuable to a women, no matter the career choice I make?

I applaud the video for being honest about women, and emphasizing that you're important to someone! But I can't help but feel like this message is redundant, especially living in such a feminist western culture. Men in general treat women like their the most important thing in the world, I'm seriously kind of jealous.

So I'll ask again, where is my song? I mean, there are women out there that still find me important and valuable in their lives even though I'm a painter and make damn near 50% of the national poverty line, right? Right? I'm sure there are, but I haven't met one yet. Nearing 30... *sigh*

comment:
this is an honest question, not intended to be a bigoted one. why is it ok for someone to just will themselves into being the opposite sex? and we're supposed to validate that? if I as a black man, hated my skin, wanted to be a white man and believed myself to be a white man on the inside, and wanted to get surgery to look like a white man, wouldn't we call that a psychological disorder? how is that any different from transgender? please do not get angry with me, be patient with me as I try to understand how this is ok.

i think no one should despise their own flesh and want to be someone else. everyone should feel beautiful and adequate in their own skin, even if it doesn't match their gender expression. I know society makes it hard. but society makes a lot things hard. you're telling me the correct response to that is to mutilate your genitalia? realizing your gender expression does not match your sex characteristics is incredibly traumatic. isn't that a red flag that there is something seriously wrong, psychologically? signed, a citizen who is genuinely concerned about our collective mental health.

author: bri 95z

comment:
Laverne Cox is GORGEOUS in this music video! Probably the most beautiful I've seen her.Â 

I'm a trans woman and beauty standards that are projected onto women very my\uch effect me. I understand that there are people that will challenge my womanhood regardless of the reality of my life and the things I experience in this world as not only a woman, but a black woman, but I felt the need to tell you that trans women are not exempt from these beauty standards. in fact, I would argue that we face them to a much more severe extent. Our bodies are checked and examined for legitimacy and this is an extent of examination that trans men I'd argue most of the time don't experience this to the same extent. Why? because they're men and while we course have beauty standards for men, these standards very rarely equate to a man's worth. Transitioning makes this very clear and the situations women are placed into rapidly become very clear to any trans woman.



I'd also like to add that there's a difference between transphobia and homophobia. Trans women and gay men are not one in the same. Many trans women are exclusively attracted to women. Gender and sexuality are different. Â 

I loved this music video on so many levels. Thank you.Â

author: Killer Kow

comment:
This is one of the most beautiful videos I've seen in a long time. It has a representation of all women, regardless of race, body type, style, age, disability, or cis/transsexual orientation, and shows that ALL women are BEAUTIFUL. And it also has such an equal representation of forms of love, whether it be romantic, platonic, familial - love between a man and a woman, love between a woman and a woman, love between sisters, love between friends, love between teammates, even what seems to be love during hardship. This video is truly inspirational and I wish all media would follow in the footsteps of those behind it. It made me cry AND it made me smile and overall it made me feel beautiful and THAT'S what it's all about.Â 
Thank you, John Legend, and thank you to Mishka Kornai, James Khabushani, Eric Cook, Zac Geoffray, and everyone associated with  #OPERATIONGIRL Â that made this happen. I've never heard of this organization before now, but I'll definitely be looking into it after watching this beautiful video.
